title: Psychophysiology 1: Introduction
topic: History, scope, and mind-body foundations of psychophysiology.

questions.question: What does the mind-body problem mainly address?

options.text: How conscious experiences relate to the physical body.
How the spinal cord controls reflexes.

questions.explanation: The mind-body problem concerns the relationship between mental and physical phenomena.

questions.question: Which statement best reflects a monist position?

options.text: Mind and body are fully separate substances.
Only behavior can be studied scientifically.
Mental and physical events are aspects of one underlying reality.
Physiology and psychology cannot be integrated.

questions.explanation: Monism proposes one underlying basis for both mind and body.

questions.question: In psychophysiology, a common design is:

options.text: physiological IV and physiological DV only.
clinical diagnosis as the only IV.

questions.explanation: A standard formulation uses behavioral manipulation and physiological dependent measures.

title: Psychophysiology 2.1: Nervous System
topic: Structural and functional organization of the human nervous system.

questions.question: Which structures form the central nervous system (CNS)?
questions.explanation: The CNS is defined as the brain plus spinal cord.

questions.question: The peripheral nervous system (PNS) includes:

options.text: Only neurons in the spinal cord.
Neural structures outside brain and spinal cord.

questions.explanation: The PNS covers neural structures outside CNS boundaries.

questions.question: Which pairing is correct?
questions.explanation: Sympathetic and parasympathetic branches have opposite dominant functions.

title: Psychophysiology 2.2: Neurons
topic: Neuron types, membrane dynamics, and neuronal signaling principles.

questions.question: Which neuron type is activated by stimuli and relays information onward?
questions.explanation: Sensory neurons are activated by stimuli and transmit signals to other neurons.

questions.question: What maintains the resting membrane potential near -70 mV?
questions.explanation: The Na+/K+ pump supports ionic gradients that sustain resting potential.

questions.question: Why do myelinated axons often conduct faster?

options.text: They use saltatory conduction between nodes.
They no longer require ion channels.

questions.explanation: Myelin enables saltatory propagation, increasing conduction velocity.

title: Psychophysiology 2.3: CNS
topic: CNS terminology, spinal pathways, and core brain organization concepts.

questions.question: A bundle of axons is called a nerve in the PNS. In the CNS it is called a:
questions.explanation: Equivalent terminology is nerve in PNS and tract in CNS.

questions.question: Afferent fibers are defined as fibers that:

options.text: Carry signals away from the CNS.

questions.explanation: Afferent means signal flow toward the CNS; efferent means away.

questions.question: Which statement is correct about spinal cord function?

options.text: It transports afferent and efferent signals between CNS and PNS.
It only controls facial expression muscles.
It replaces forebrain processing in cognition.

questions.explanation: The spinal cord is a key bidirectional pathway for sensory and motor signaling.

questions.question: Biosignals are best defined as:

options.text: Indirect estimates with no time dimension.

questions.explanation: Biosignals are direct, time-varying physiological measurements.

questions.question: In unipolar recording, what is true about the reference?

options.text: Each channel must have a different reference.
All channels are measured against a shared reference.
A truly neutral site always exists on the body.

questions.explanation: Unipolar recordings use a common reference despite no perfectly neutral body site.

questions.question: If the highest frequency of interest is 100 Hz, Nyquist implies at least:
questions.explanation: Nyquist requires at least twice the highest frequency component.

questions.question: Operationalization means:

options.text: Defining constructs in specific measurable terms.
Fitting a statistical model before data collection.

questions.explanation: Operationalization turns abstract constructs into measurable criteria.

questions.question: Why are within-subject designs often preferred in psychophysiology?

options.text: Within-person variability is often lower than between-person variability.

questions.explanation: Lower within-person variance can improve sensitivity.

questions.question: Counterbalancing in block designs mainly helps control:
questions.explanation: Counterbalancing mitigates temporal and sequence confounds.

title: Psychophysiology 5: Electromyography
topic: EMG physiology, recording practice, and signal processing.

questions.question: A motor unit consists of:

options.text: One sensory neuron and surrounding glia.
One motor neuron, its axon, and all innervated muscle fibers.
All muscles used in a movement.
One muscle fiber and all cortical inputs.

questions.explanation: A motor unit is defined by one motor neuron and the fibers it innervates.

questions.question: Surface EMG most directly reflects:

options.text: Summed muscle fiber action potentials from active motor units.

questions.explanation: Surface EMG captures peripheral muscle electrical activity.

questions.question: A common EMG processing sequence is:
questions.explanation: A common flow is rectify, smooth, then integrate for robust output measures.

title: Psychophysiology 6.1: Cardiovascular System
topic: Cardiovascular structure, cardiac conduction, and autonomic modulation.

questions.question: The cardiovascular system primarily serves to:

options.text: Transport blood for oxygen/nutrient delivery and waste removal.

questions.explanation: Its core function is transport to support tissue metabolism and homeostasis.

questions.question: Autorhythmicity means some cardiac cells can:
questions.explanation: Pacemaker cells self-depolarize, providing intrinsic rhythm generation.

questions.question: Which statement about SA and AV nodes is correct?

options.text: AV node sets the fastest intrinsic rhythm.
SA node initiates rhythm; AV node provides a brief conduction delay.
Both nodes only act under parasympathetic drive.

questions.explanation: SA node usually dominates pacing; AV delay supports coordinated pumping.

title: Psychophysiology 6.2: Cardiovascular Measures
topic: Blood pressure, plethysmography, ECG, and HRV in psychophysiology.

questions.question: Systemic blood pressure is mainly determined by:
questions.explanation: A core hemodynamic model combines cardiac output with vascular resistance.

questions.question: In baroreflex control, increased sensed blood pressure tends to cause:

options.text: A compensatory decrease in cardiac output.

questions.explanation: Baroreflex uses negative feedback to counter pressure increases.

questions.question: Why is HRV useful in psychophysiology?

options.text: It directly replaces blood pressure measurement.
It helps separate parasympathetic and sympathetic influences on heart dynamics.
It only indexes skeletal muscle fatigue.

questions.explanation: HRV analysis can reveal autonomic modulation patterns in cardiac timing.

title: Psychophysiology 7: Electrodermal Activity
topic: Skin physiology, sweat gland activity, and EDA interpretation.

questions.question: The main physiological origin of skin conductance changes is:

options.text: Cortical action potentials at the scalp.

questions.explanation: EDA conductance changes are primarily linked to eccrine sweat gland activity.

questions.question: Eccrine glands relevant to EDA are mainly under:
questions.explanation: EDA is commonly interpreted as a sympathetic-linked measure.

questions.question: How are SCL and SCR typically distinguished?

options.text: SCL is phasic and SCR is tonic.
SCL is tonic/slow and SCR is phasic/event-related.
They are identical metrics with different names.

questions.explanation: SCL tracks slower baseline-like level; SCR captures transient event-related responses.

title: Psychophysiology 8.1: Electrocortical Activity
topic: EEG physiological origin, volume conduction, and modality limits.

questions.question: Scalp EEG primarily measures:

options.text: Voltage changes related to neural activity.

questions.explanation: EEG is an electrical voltage measurement linked to neural processes.

questions.question: The strongest contributors to scalp EEG are usually:

options.text: Summed synchronous postsynaptic potentials in large cortical populations.

questions.explanation: Large-scale synchronous postsynaptic activity is most detectable at the scalp.

questions.question: A key implication of volume conduction is that:

options.text: Signals from one source can appear across multiple scalp regions.
It provides exact source localization by itself.

questions.explanation: Volume conduction spreads electrical fields and complicates direct source attribution.

title: Psychophysiology 8.2: Electrocortical Measures
topic: EEG setup, oscillatory measures, ERP methods, and analysis families.

questions.question: Which statement about EEG reference electrodes is most accurate?

options.text: A perfectly neutral reference location always exists.
All channels should have unrelated references.
No reference is needed with active electrodes.
A practical common reference is used even though no site is truly neutral.

questions.explanation: EEG uses practical reference choices because perfectly neutral sites do not exist.

questions.question: For EEG content up to 100 Hz, a valid setup is:

options.text: At least 200 Hz sampling with appropriate anti-alias low-pass filtering.
100 Hz sampling with no anti-alias filter.
20 Hz sampling because EEG is slow.

questions.explanation: Nyquist and anti-aliasing require at least double-rate sampling and suitable filtering.

questions.question: Epoching and averaging in ERP analysis are used to:

options.text: Isolate event-locked activity while reducing unrelated noise.
Eliminate the need for event markers.
Force all frequency bands to equal power.
Convert EEG into blood pressure estimates.

questions.explanation: Averaging time-locked epochs emphasizes consistent event-related components.
